stem: The labor and delivery nurse is assessing three clients. Based on the documentation in the EHR, match the Fetal Heart Rate (FHR) finding to its most likely physiological cause.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Client 1: 39y/o G3P2 at 41 weeks. Oligohydramnios documented on yesterday's ultrasound. 
Client 2: 24y/o G1P0 at 38 weeks. Currently 9cm dilated. Fetal head is visible at the introitus during contractions. 
Client 3: 31y/o G1P0 at 40 weeks. Client reports severe nausea and lightheadedness following the administration of an epidural block.

tabs.title: Ultrasound Result
tabs.content:
Client 1: Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) < 5 cm (Oligohydramnios). 
Client 3: Placenta posterior, no evidence of abruption.

rows.text: Abrupt decelerations (V, U, or W-shaped) occurring at varying times
Gradual decelerations that begin and end with the contraction ('mirroring')
Gradual decelerations that begin after the contraction peak and return late

rationale.correct: Abrupt decelerations (r1) are **Variables**, caused by Cord Compression (often due to Oligohydramnios, as seen in Client 1). Gradual decelerations that mirror the contraction (r2) are **Earlies**, caused by Head Compression (Client 2 is 9cm dilated/crowning). Gradual decelerations that start late (r3) are **Lates**, caused by Uteroplacental Insufficiency (often due to maternal hypotension, seen in Client 3).
clinicalPearls: Early decelerations require no intervention; just continue monitoring.
Variables often require maternal position change (Side-lying or Knee-chest).
Late decelerations require the 'LION' protocol: Left-side, IV bolus, Oxygen, Notify provider.

questionTrap.trap: Believing all Earlies require fetal scalp stimulation.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Earlies are normal during active labor/descent. Do not treat them as an emergency.

mnemonic.title: VEAL CHOP
mnemonic.expansion: V-Variable = C-Cord. E-Early = H-Head. A-Accels = O-Ok. L-Late = P-Placenta.
